DA4BCI 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Entropy-Regularized OT (Sinkhorn–Knopp) with Barycentric Mapping

    domain_adaptation_ot.Rd

    The domain_adaptation_ot function computes a balanced, entropy-regularized optimal transport (OT) coupling between source_data and target_data using the Sinkhorn–Knopp iterations with uniform marginals. It then applies the barycentric mapping \(X_s \mapsto P X_t / (P \mathbf{1})\) to align source samples toward the target domain.

    domain_adaptation_ot(
  source_data,
  target_data,
  eps = 0.05,
  maxit = 500,
  tol = 1e-07,
  cost = c("sqeuclidean", "euclidean")
)

    Arguments

    source_data

    A numeric matrix of size \(n \times d\) (source samples by features).

    target_data

    A numeric matrix of size \(m \times d\) (target samples by features).

    eps

    Positive entropy regularization parameter (default 0.05).

    maxit

    Maximum Sinkhorn iterations (default 500).

    tol

    Stopping tolerance on marginal feasibility (default 1e-7).

    cost

    Cost type: "sqeuclidean" (default) or "euclidean".

    Value

    A list containing:

    weighted_source_data

    The barycentrically mapped source data \(P X_t / (P \mathbf{1})\).

    target_data

    The original target data (possibly to be used downstream).

    ot_plan

    The OT coupling matrix \(P \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times m}\).

    cost

    The transport cost matrix \(C\).

    epsilon

    The regularization parameter actually used.

    iterations

    Number of Sinkhorn iterations performed.

    converged

    Logical flag indicating whether the marginal residual met tol.

    residual

    Final infinity-norm marginal residual.

    Details

    This function solves the balanced, entropy-regularized OT problem $$\min_{P \ge 0} \langle P, C \rangle + \epsilon \sum_{ij} P_{ij}(\log P_{ij} - 1)$$ subject to \(P \mathbf{1}_m = r\), \(\mathbf{1}_n^\top P = c^\top\), where \(r = \mathbf{1}_n/n\) and \(c = \mathbf{1}_m/m\). The coupling is computed via the Sinkhorn–Knopp updates with kernel \(K = \exp(-C/\epsilon)\). The barycentric map transports each source point to the convex combination of target points weighted by the corresponding row of \(P\).

    References

    Cuturi, M. (2013). Sinkhorn Distances: Lightspeed Computation of Optimal Transport. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 26. Courty, N., Flamary, R., Tuia, D., & Rakotomamonjy, A. (2017). Optimal Transport for Domain Adaptation. IEEE TPAMI, 39(9), 1853–1865.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
set.seed(123)
src <- matrix(rnorm(100), nrow = 20, ncol = 5)
tgt <- matrix(rnorm(100, mean = 2), nrow = 20, ncol = 5)

ot_result <- domain_adaptation_ot(src, tgt, eps = 0.05, maxit = 1000, tol = 1e-8)
aligned_source <- ot_result$weighted_source_data
aligned_target <- ot_result$target_data
dim(aligned_source)  # 20 x 5
dim(aligned_target)  # 20 x 5
} # }
